questions.text:
A 36-year-old man comes to the office because of several months of fatigue and weight loss. The patient has not traveled outside of the United States. Past medical history is unremarkable. He does not take any medications. He has been sexually active with three female partners over the past two years. The patient has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past five years. He consumes alcohol occasionally. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals mild scleral icterus. Laboratory results are shown below. After further evaluation, the patient is started on antiviral therapy with entecavir. Which of the following stages in the viral replication cycle is affected by this medication?

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue and weight loss. Laboratory testing reveals a positive HBsAg, high HBV viral load, and negative HBeAg. In combination, these findings suggest chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. This patient is started on antiviral therapy with entecavir, a nucleoside analog that inhibits DNA replication and transcription.

Hepatitis B medications can be divided into two groups based on their mechanism of action: nucleoside (e.g., entecavir, lamivudine) or nucleotide analogs (e.g., adefovir, tenofovir) and interferons.

In infected cells, the nucleotide/nucleoside analogs are first phosphorylated by cellular enzymes into either a diphosphate or triphosphate form to resemble the natural nucleotides present in the cells. Viral DNA polymerase will try to use these analogues for DNA synthesis. However, once these analogs are incorporated into the growing DNA strand, no additional nucleotides can be added, and DNA synthesis stops.

Side effects of nucleotide/nucleoside analogs include nephrotoxicity (adefovir), headache, dizziness, fatigue, and nausea. HBV strains can develop resistance to medications from this class through mutations in the DNA polymerase enzyme.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cell entry:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide blocks the action of viral fusion proteins and prevents viruses from entering the cell. It is an antiretroviral agent used to manage HIV infection, not hepatitis B infection.  
✅ Replication of viral DNA:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Post-translational modifications:
Incorrect: Protease inhibitors are synthetic drugs that inhibit the action of HIV-1 protease, an enzyme that cleaves precursor proteins into smaller fragments. These fragments are needed for viral growth, infectivity, and replication. Examples of protease inhibitors include ritonavir and indinavir.  
❌ Translation of viral proteins:
Incorrect: Interferon activates host cell ribonucleases, which preferentially degrade viral mRNA and prevent translation of viral mRNA into proteins. In contrast, entecavir is a nucleotide analog that inhibits the transcription of viral DNA into mRNA  
❌ Release from host cells:
Incorrect: Neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) are a class of medication that blocks the enzyme neuraminidase. NAIs can be used to treat influenza infection by preventing viral progeny release from the host cells. Examples of NAIs include zanamivir and oseltamivir.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the office because of fatigue, joint pain, and muscle aches. The patient has experienced a 6-month history of progressive tiredness associated with dull achy pain in the knees, hips, and shoulders. He has no significant past medical history, and he does not regularly take medications. He has a history of intravenous drug use and was undomiciled in his early 30s. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient is started on a medication that inhibits the production of guanine nucleotides through competitive inhibition of inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase. Which of the following medications was this patient prescribed?
 
Laboratory Value  
Result
Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL  
Leukocyte count  
8,000 mm3   
Platelet count  
230,000 mm3   
Viral profile  

HAV IgM  
Negative
HAV IgG  
Positive
HBsAg  
Positive
HBeAg
Negative
HBV IgG  
Positive
HCV IgG  
Positive
HCV RNA  
100,000,000 IU/ml
questions.solution:
This patient has fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, positive hepatitis C virus (HCV) antibody titers, and high levels of HCV RNA. These findings are consistent with HCV infection. He was most likely started on ribavirin for management of this infection.

Ribavirin is a nucleoside analog that is initially phosphorylated to a monophosphate form. Ribavirin monophosphate resembles inosine-5′-phosphate (IMP) and binds to IMP dehydrogenase, which converts IMP into xanthosine monophosphate. Xanthosein monophosphate then goes on to make guanine nucleotides. The binding of ribavirin to IMP dehydrogenase inhibits the enzyme, thereby reducing guanine nucleotide production and viral RNA synthesis.

Side effects of systemic ribavirin therapy include dose-dependent hemolytic anemia and hyperuricemia. Aerosolized ribavirin may cause conjunctival and bronchial irritation. Ribavirin is a known human teratogen and is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Similarly, sofosbuvir is a nucleotide analog used to treat HCV infection. This medication inhibits HCV RNA polymerase. When used alone or in combination with interferon or ribavirin, sofosbuvir can achieve very high cure rates (90–95%).  

Option Analysis

❌ Oseltamivir:
Incorrect: Oseltamivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor. It blocks the function of neuraminidase, an enzyme produced by the influenza virus, and prevents the release of newly synthesized virus from the host cell. Furthermore, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with hepatitis C infection, which is not treated with oseltamivir.  
❌ Entecavir:
Incorrect: Entecavir is a nucleoside analog incorporated into growing viral DNA strands to block further genetic material synthesis. It is indicated in chronic hepatitis B virus infection management, not hepatitis C virus infection.  
✅ Ribavirin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Enfuvirtide:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide blocks the action of viral fusion proteins and prevents the virus from entering the target cell. It is an antiretroviral agent used in the management of HIV infection. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with hepatitis C virus infection.  
❌ Interferon-gamma:
Incorrect: Interferon-gamma is a cytokine that activates macrophages and induces class II major histocompatibility complex (MHC) expression. Exogenous interferon-gamma can be used therapeutically in chronic granulomatous disease and osteopetrosis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the office because of a three-month history of epigastric pain, weight loss, and nausea. Over the last three months, the patient has lost 30-lbs (13.6 kg). She says, “My pants are fitting looser than usual.” She also reports that food is not as appetizing as it used to be. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. Family history is noncontributory. Biopsy from an upper endoscopy reveals an adenocarcinoma of the gastric antrum, of intestinal-type. Which of the following additional findings could be present on physical examination if the gastric carcinoma has metastasized?
questions.solution:
Malignancy of the stomach can reach an advanced stage before becoming clinically symptomatic. One of the first spots where these tumors metastasize is to the left supraclavicular lymph node through the thoracic duct (Virchow node).   

Visible enlargement of Virchow node (Troisier sign) results from the carcinomatous involvement of the supraclavicular nodes at the junction of the thoracic duct and the left subclavian vein. It can be an early sign of gastric cancer. Usually, Troisier sign is caused by metastatic gastric carcinoma, although supraclavicular nodal involvement can also be seen in other gastrointestinal, thoracic, and pelvic cancers. Gastric cancers tend to metastasize to this region through migration of tumor emboli through the thoracic duct, where subdiaphragmatic lymphatic drainage enters the venous circulation in the left subclavian vein.



Option Analysis

❌ Courvoisier sign:
Incorrect: Courvoisier sign is the presence of a palpably enlarged gallbladder in patients with mild jaundice unlikely to be caused by gallstones. This sign indicates possible malignancy of the gallbladder or pancreas.  
✅ Enlarged Virchow node:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Murphy sign:
Incorrect: Murphy sign is inspiratory arrest with deep palpation of the upper right quadrant while the patient takes a deep breath. Inspiratory arrest is a positive Murphy sign and indicates an inflamed gallbladder. It is useful for differentiating pain in the right upper quadrant and is specifically seen in acute cholecystitis. This patient has signs and symptoms consistent with gastric malignancy.  
❌ Right supraclavicular adenopathy :
Incorrect: Right supraclavicular adenopathy is associated with cancer in the mediastinum, lungs, or esophagus, but not typically gastric cancer.  
❌ Chvostek sign:
Incorrect: The Chvostek sign is a clinical sign of hypocalcemia which consists of twitching of muscles innervated by the facial nerve. It refers to an abnormal reaction to the stimulation of the facial nerve. It is not commonly seen in gastric malignancy.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the office of his primary care physician because of progressive weight loss and yellow discoloration of skin. The patient reports that he had lost approximately 8 kgs (17.6 lb) over the past 3 months. The patient also complains of dark urine and pale stools. Review of systems is positive for heartburn and mild upper abdominal pain for the past few months. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed five years ago. The patient has a 30-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes a day. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows scleral and cutaneous icterus. The lungs are clear to auscultation and no abnormal heart sounds are heard. CT scan of the abdomen is shown below. Which of the following additional findings can be seen in this patient?  



Reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Dark rings that encircle the iris of the eyes
Palpable nodule bulging into the umbilicus

questions.solution:
This patient with obstructive jaundice and a mass of the head of pancreas, most likely has pancreatic cancer.    

The most common type is the cancer of the pancreatic head, which accounts for the most cases of hepatobiliary obstruction. Because of the posterior relationships of the pancreas, cancer of the head often compresses and obstructs the bile duct and/or the hepatopancreatic ampulla. This causes obstruction, resulting in the retention of bile pigments, painless enlargement of the gallbladder (Courvoisier sign), and obstructive jaundice. Courvoisier’s law states that an enlarged and non-tender gallbladder accompanied by mild jaundice is unlikely caused by gallstones and rather caused by pancreatic or gallstone cancer. Weight loss can occur due to high tumor metabolism or to pancreatic insufficiency.  

Among others, pancreatic cancer can invade major arteries, like the superior mesenteric artery, which lies posterior to the neck of the pancreas. When the superior mesenteric artery is invaded, it usually means that the cancer cannot be surgically resected. On the other hand, cancer of the neck and body of the pancreas may cause hepatic portal or inferior vena caval obstruction because the pancreas overlies these large veins.  



Option Analysis

❌ Renal artery bruit:
Incorrect: Renal artery bruit can be heard in patients with renal artery stenosis, which is characterized by resistant hypertension. This patient’s vitals are within normal limits, and the CT scan abdomen is significant for the mass of the head of the pancreas.  
❌ Increased liver span:
Incorrect: Increased liver span is a nonspecific finding that can be seen in a number of infectious (e.g., hepatitis and infectious mononucleosis), biliary (e.g., biliary sclerosing cholangitis) and neoplastic (e.g., hepatocellular carcinoma) conditions. This patient’s yellow skin and sclera and association with a mass of the pancreatic head is suggestive of pancreatic cancer.  
❌ Dark rings that encircle the iris of the eyes:
Incorrect: Kayser–Fleischer rings, characterized by dark rings that encircle the iris of the eyes, are pathognomonic of Wilson disease, which results from accumulation of copper in the liver and decreased excretion in bile. It is characterized by fatigue, abdominal pain, and uncontrolled or poorly coordinated movements. Pancreatic head involvement, as seen in this abdominal CT scan, is not a feature of Wilson disease.  
✅ Palpable non-tender gallbladder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Palpable nodule bulging into the umbilicus:
Incorrect: The Sister Mary Joseph sign, characterized by a palpable nodule bulging into the umbilicus, is typically seen in patients with gastric cancer. Although it can cause weight loss and abdominal pain, a pancreatic mass in this patient is suggestive of pancreatic carcinoma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and early satiety for the past three months. His clothes are looser than usual. Past medical history is significant for hypertension managed with lisinopril. Family history is noncontributory. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history, drinks alcohol occasionally, and does not use other recreational drugs. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a thin, pale, and cachexic man. Abdominal examination is significant for an enlarged spleen on palpation. CT scan abdomen shows an irregular mass arising posteriorly from the greater curvature of the stomach and compressing the splenic vessels. If the mass continues to enlarge, tissue supplied by which of the following vessels is most likely to be compromised in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation suggests a gastric tumor compressing the splenic vessels posteriorly. The splenic artery originates from the celiac artery and courses superiorly to the pancreas, giving off branches to the stomach and pancreas before reaching the spleen. These branches include: 
  •  Greater pancreatic artery and dorsal pancreatic artery 
  •  Short gastric arteries 
  •  Left gastroepiploic artery 
  •  Posterior gastric artery 
The short gastric arteries supply the fundus of the stomach along the proximal greater curvature where they have very poor anastomoses if the splenic artery is blocked. Therefore, this area is vulnerable to ischemia in the case of splenic artery blockage. In contrast, the left gastroepiploic artery which supplies the body of the stomach at the greater curvature forms strong anastomoses with the right gastroepiploic artery, and this region is usually spared from ischemia if the splenic artery is blocked.  



Option Analysis

✅ Short gastric arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left gastric artery:
Incorrect: The left gastric artery arises from the celiac artery and runs along the superior portion of the lesser curvature of the stomach. It anastomoses with the right gastric artery, which runs right to left. Splenic vessel compression would not involve the lesser curvature.  
❌ Gastroduodenal artery:
Incorrect:  Gastroduodenal arteries (branch of the common hepatic artery) supply the pylorus of the stomach and the duodenal bulb. This region would not be affected by splenic artery obstruction.  
❌ Proper hepatic artery:
Incorrect: Proper hepatic artery is a branch of the common hepatic artery, which supplies blood to the liver and gallbladder. Splenic artery obstruction would not affect these structures.  
❌ Left gastroepiploic artery:
Incorrect: The left gastroepiploic artery is a branch of the splenic artery that supplies blood to the body of the stomach along the greater curvature. It forms an anastomosis with the right gastroepiploic artery (branch of the gastroduodenal artery). Therefore, this region of the stomach would not be at risk for ischemia with splenic artery blockage.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a several month history of epigastric abdominal pain, weight loss, fatigue, and early satiety. The patient's medical history is notable for a 20-pack-year smoking history, recurrent peptic ulcer disease, coronary artery disease, and hypertension. The patient’s H. pylori stool antigen assay is positive. The patient undergoes endoscopy with biopsy and the following image is obtained:  



 Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Which of the following is most likely to be observed on histologic analysis?

choices.text: Irregular tubular structures and dysplasia projecting through the muscularis mucosa
Mucinous cells floating in an abundant extracellular mucin pool
Large gastric folds with elongated pits and cystically dilated gastric glands
Prominent rugal folds and hypertrophic parietal cells

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has a history concerning for previous peptic ulcer disease, H. pylori infection, and an endoscopic image concerning for malignancy. Intestinal gastric carcinoma is described morphologically as irregular, with an uneven base, asymmetric edges and a disrupted or moth-eaten appearance with heaped up margins, which is consistent with the endoscopic image presented.  

Risk factors for intestinal gastric adenocarcinoma include diets high in nitrosamines (a component of smoked foods), smoking, and chronic H. pylori infection. The disease usually results from long standing untreated peptic ulcer disease or gastritis. Over time, chronic inflammation promotes gastric atrophy which progresses to metaplasia, dysplasia, and then eventually to carcinoma. As the cancer invades the gastric lining, it invades the muscularis mucosa, projecting to the outer layer of the stomach lining.  

Option Analysis

✅ Irregular tubular structures and dysplasia projecting through the muscularis mucosa:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mucinous cells floating in an abundant extracellular mucin pool:
Incorrect: This histologic description is that of diffuse gastric cancer, which is primarily composed of signet ring cells. This type of gastric cancer is more commonly related to genetic predisposition, as opposed to environmental risk factors.   
❌ Foamy macrophages in lamina propria :
Incorrect: Whipple disease is due to intestinal infection with Tropheryma whipplei. This disease results in malabsorption, and cardiac, neurologic and arthritic symptoms, which are absent in this patient. The endoscopy image shows a gastric ulcer, as opposed to an intestinal ulcer, making this diagnosis unlikely as well.   
❌ Large gastric folds with elongated pits and cystically dilated gastric glands:
Incorrect: Ménétriers disease is a rare disease characterized by large rugal folds, decreased acid production, and protein loss. The treatment for this disease is gastrectomy due to the increased risk of developing gastric carcinoma.   
❌ Prominent rugal folds and hypertrophic parietal cells:
Incorrect: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is characterized by parietal cell hyperplasia due to a gastrin secreting tumor. The disease results in the generation of multiple peptic ulcers and prominent rugal folds due to mucosal hyperplasia.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman comes to the primary care physician with a several month history of worsening epigastric pain, weight loss, and early satiety. The patient reports she has lost 11.3 kg (25-lbs) in the last 3 months. Physical examination shows a thin, middle-aged female with hyperpigmented, velvety axillary skin folds and tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. A secretin stimulation test results in a < 200 ng/L increase in serum gastrin. An upper endoscopy with biopsy is performed, demonstrating the following histologic image. Which of the following is the underlying genetic mutation causing this disease process?  



Reproduced from: wikipedia

choices.text: Loss of cell adhesion protein E-cadherin
Increased activation of transforming growth factor-alpha (TGFa)
Autosomal dominant inheritance of a mutation in MEN1
Autosomal dominant inheritance of a mutation LKB1
Autosomal dominant mutation of APC tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 5q

questions.solution:
Diffuse-type gastric adenocarcinoma is an aggressive form of gastric cancer most commonly due to genetic mutations in loss of expression of CDH1, the gene that encodes E-cadherin.  This cell surface protein is involved in intercellular connections, maintaining epithelial organization, and controlling the progression of cell cycle. Due to this epithelial disruption, the stomach takes upon a thickened, leathery appearance known as linitis plastica. Histologic analysis of this tumor will demonstrate mucin-filled cells with peripheral nuclei, referred to as signet ring cells.     

Diffuse gastric cancer follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, with most patients diagnosed in middle age. Common presenting symptoms include weight loss, abdominal pain, nausea, and early satiety. Dermatologic findings may include the sudden appearance of diffuse seborrheic keratoses (Leser-Trelat sign) or acanthosis nigricans, which is characterized by velvety and darkly pigmented patches on skin folds. Treatment depends upon the extent of disease, and prophylactic gastrectomy is recommended for any individual with a germline CDH1 mutation and appropriate family history.  

Option Analysis

✅ Loss of cell adhesion protein E-cadherin  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Increased activation of transforming growth factor-alpha (TGFa)  :
Incorrect: Increased activation of transforming growth factor alpha is thought to underlie the pathologic genetic processes resulting in Ménétrier’s disease, not diffuse gastric cancer.  
❌ Autosomal dominant inheritance of a mutation in MEN1:
Incorrect: MEN1 encodes the protein menin, which acts as a tumor suppressor regulating DNA transcription and apoptosis. It is commonly implicated in a hereditary condition associated with tumors of the endocrine glands, including gastrinomas and subsequent Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. In this vignette, the patient’s secretin stimulation test is negative, making a gastrin-secreting tumor very unlikely.    
❌ Autosomal dominant inheritance of a mutation LKB1:
Incorrect: LKB1 is a tumor suppressor gene thought to be implicated in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. This disease often presents with benign hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract and hyperpigmented macules on the lips and oral mucosa. The hyperpigmented areas in this vignette are instead reflective of acanthosis nigricans.   
❌ Autosomal dominant mutation of APC tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 5q:
Incorrect: This mutation describes the genetic mechanism of familial adenomatous polyposis, which results in thousands of colon polyps and progresses to colorectal cancer in 100% of cases.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a painless mass in his left neck. The patient reports rapid enlargement of this mass over the past several weeks. In addition, he reports a 20-lb (9.1 kg) weight loss, fatigue, and decreased appetite. Past medical history is notable for recurrent peptic ulcer disease, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. He reports a 10-pack-year smoking history but quit 25 years ago. He reports drinking 1-2 beers per day.  Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 12/min and blood pressure is 142/62 mmHg. Physical examination shows a hard 3 cm x  3 cm mass in the left supraclavicular fossa, temporal wasting, epigastric tenderness to palpation, and a small periumbilical subcutaneous nodule. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Enlargement of the Virchow node, or the left supraclavicular lymph node draining the thoracic duct, is also known as Troisier sign, which is commonly found in patients with underlying gastric adenocarcinoma. This finding, in conjunction with this patient's periumbilical metastases known as Sister-Mary Joseph nodules, weight loss, early satiety, and history of recurrent peptic ulcer disease, makes gastric cancer the most likely diagnosis.  

Other physical exam findings commonly seen with gastric adenocarcinoma include the sudden appearance of diffuse seborrheic keratoses (Leser-Trelat sign) or acanthosis nigricans, which is characterized by velvety and darkly pigmented patches of skin folds. A finding known as Blumer shelf may also be felt on digital rectal exam, which indicates metastatic tumor cells growing in the rectovesical or rectouterine pouch.  

Option Analysis

✅ Gastric adenocarcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hodgkin Lymphoma:
Incorrect: Hodgkin lymphoma may present with enlarged non-tender supraclavicular lymph nodes but usually presents with associated night sweats, fevers and splenomegaly. This patient’s epigastric pain is likely indicative of another underlying condition.  
❌ Pancreatic adenocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Pancreatic cancer typically presents with jaundice and unexplained weight loss. Metastases may be present in the supraclavicular or periumbilical nodes, but the absence of jaundice in this patient makes pancreatic cancer less likely.   
❌ Colonic adenocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Colorectal cancer typically presents with weight loss, rectal bleeding, or progressive change in bowel movements. Metastases to the supraclavicular lymph nodes are possible; however, this patient’s other clinical signs (e.g., Sister-Mary Joseph nodules) are indicative of another underlying malignancy.   
❌ Hepatocellular carcinoma  :
Incorrect: Hepatocellular carcinoma is largely a consequence of untreated cirrhosis. This patient is without evidence of ascites, jaundice, or blood dyscrasias, making this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a chief complaint of a new rash that suddenly appeared several days ago. He reports the rash is not itchy, and he has not had a similar rash in the past. When questioned further, the patient reports a several-month history of abdominal pain, weight loss, early satiety, and fatigue. He reports discomfort in the mid-epigastrium postprandially that started one year ago and has worsened. The patient took a proton pump-inhibitor, which initially alleviated the pain but now has no effect on symptoms. He has lost 9.1-kg (20-lb) over the past six months. Further past medical history includes coronary artery disease, hypertension, recurrent H. pylori gastritis, and a twenty one pack year smoking history. Physical examination shows multiple seborrheic keratoses on his chest and back, as well as temporal wasting. Multiple enlarged supraclavicular lymph nodes are noted, predominantly on the left side. Laboratory results reveal a hemoglobin level of 8.0 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume of 70 fL. Which of the following findings is most likely to be present on endoscopic evaluation?

choices.text: Ulcerated mass on the lesser curvature with raised margins
Grossly thickened stomach wall with a leathery appearance
Fibrotic tissue at the pyloric sphincter
Round defect with a smooth base on the lesser curvature
Ill-defined white-yellow mass extruding from the sphincter of Oddi

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with a history of weight loss, early satiety, fatigue, a Leser-Trélat sign (the sudden appearance of diffuse seborrheic keratoses), and enlarged Virchow's node is concerning for intestinal gastric adenocarcinoma. Gastric adenocarcinoma is generally asymptomatic until the cancer is at an advanced stage. Typical signs and symptoms include weight loss, anorexia, dyspepsia, dysphagia, epigastric pain, and early satiety. The development of dysphagia is a common symptom when the tumors involve the proximal stomach or cardia. Additionally, some patients may develop upper gastrointestinal bleeding, causing hematemesis or melena.  

Gastric cancer is divided into two subtypes: intestinal and diffuse. Risk factors for intestinal gastric adenocarcinoma include diets high in nitrosamines (a component of smoked foods), smoking, and chronic H. pylori infection. In contrast, diffuse gastric cancer more commonly arises as a result of genetic mutations and is not associated with chronic H. pylori infection. In either case, advanced disease classically metastasizes to the supraclavicular lymph nodes (Virchow node), periumbilical lymph nodes (Sister Mary Joseph Nodule), and to the ovaries in biological females (Krukenberg tumor). Overall survival for gastric adenocarcinoma is poor due to its paucity of signs and symptoms until late in the disease process. Treatment typically involves chemotherapy or surgical resection, depending on the burden of disease.   

Option Analysis

✅ Ulcerated mass on the lesser curvature with raised margins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Grossly thickened stomach wall with a leathery appearance:
Incorrect: Linitis plastica is the gross pathological description of diffuse gastric cancer. This type of gastric adenocarcinoma is more commonly hereditary and is not associated with chronic H. pylori infection. Diffuse gastric adenocarcinomas secrete copious amounts of mucus. The mucus inside the cell pushes the nucleus to the periphery, giving it the histologic nomenclature of a “signet-ring cell.”  
❌ Fibrotic tissue at the pyloric sphincter:
Incorrect: Gastric outlet obstruction is characterized by a physical obstruction at the gastric pylorus, which is more commonly due to fibrotic tissue in older patients with a history of untreated duodenal peptic ulcer disease. These obstructions are generally characterized by recurrent non-bilious vomiting. The condition is less likely in this patient with associated systemic features concerning for an underlying malignancy.  
❌ Round defect with a smooth base on the lesser curvature :
Incorrect: Discomfort in the mid-epigastrium relieved by proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) is typical in peptic ulcer disease. Benign ulcers typically have smooth bases with regular borders. However, this patient has systemic features concerning for an underlying malignancy, and the pain has stopped responding to PPIs.  
❌ Ill-defined white-yellow mass extruding from the sphincter of Oddi:
Incorrect: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma typically presents with painless jaundice and weight loss. Similar to gastric adenocarcinoma, patients may also present with a Leser-Trélat sign and enlarged supraclavicular lymph nodes. However, without associated jaundice, a diagnosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma is less likely.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the office because of persistent dyspepsia. The patient has been taking a high dose of omeprazole for two months with some improvement in the symptoms, but he still complains of mild, burning epigastric pain alleviated by eating. As a result, he has gained 6.8-kg (15-lb) over this period of time. In addition, he complains of foul smelling, non-bloody diarrhea 1-2 times daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 142/62 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. The patient undergoes esophagogastroduodenoscopy, which reveals multiple ulcers in the proximal and distal duodenum. Biopsies of the ulcers are negative for Helicobacter pylori. Which of the following findings is diagnostic of this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presentation of proton pump inhibitor-resistant peptic ulcer disease, negative H. pylori biopsy, and findings of multiple ulcers on endoscopy is concerning for Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) due to an underlying gastrinoma. Gastrinomas are pancreatic or duodenal tumors that secrete excess gastrin, resulting in hyperplasia of parietal cells and hypersecretion of gastric acid. Over time, the excess acid exceeds the neutralizing capacity of pancreatic bicarbonate secretions, resulting in multiple peptic ulcers. Additionally, the low pH of intestinal contents inactivates pancreatic digestive enzymes, resulting in malabsorption and steatorrhea.  

Once ZES is suspected, initial testing includes measurement of serum gastrin and gastric pH. A serum gastrin concentration of >1,000 pg/mL, in addition to gastric pH <2 is diagnostic of ZES and highly suggestive of a gastrinoma; however, gastrinomas have been discovered at gastrin concentrations as low as 150 pg/mL. If the serum gastrin concentration is equivocal, a secretin stimulation test should be administered. In the setting of ZES, this typically will then show a gastrin concentration of >1,000 pg/mL in addition to gastric pH <2, confirming the diagnosis of ZES. Treatment of ZES involves medical management with a high dose proton pump inhibitor, octreotide, as well as resection of the gastrinoma for localized disease.    

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated serum gastrin levels  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevated CEA levels:
Incorrect: Elevated CEA levels are used in monitoring for recurrence of colorectal cancer. CEA is not implicated in testing for Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.   
❌ Elevated serum chromogranin A levels:
Incorrect: Chromogranin A levels are commonly elevated in patients with gastrinomas; however, the finding is non-specific and can be seen in other conditions as well, including pheochromocytoma, pancreatic cancer, and additional neuroendocrine tumors.  
❌ Elevated serum cancer antigen 19-9 levels:
Incorrect: CA19-9 is a tumor marker for pancreatic cancer, which more commonly presents with painless jaundice and weight loss, which this patient does not have.   
❌ Genetic analysis of RET:
Incorrect: Gastrinomas are associated with mutations in MEN 1, but they are not seen in patients with MEN 2A or 2B, which are caused by mutations in the RET proto-oncogene.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and vomiting. The pain started five hours ago, originated around the umbilicus, and migrated to the right lower quadrant. The pain is stabbing in nature and has been progressively worsening. She has also vomited twice and has no appetite. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), blood pressure is 147/82 mmHg, and pulse is 91/min. On physical examination, right lower quadrant tenderness is noted. Ultrasound of the abdomen confirms appendiceal inflammation, and the patient is taken to the operating room for an appendectomy. Postoperative examination of the appendiceal specimen reveals a mass blocking the lumen of the appendix. Histological examination of the mass shows small cells with uniform round to oval nuclei and abundant granules that stain positive for synaptophysin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of appendicitis. Postoperative histological analysis reveals the presence of cells that stain positive for synaptophysin. Although most cases of appendicitis develop due to obstruction of the appendiceal lumen by a fecalith, some rare cases arise due to an obstructing tumor. This patient’s tumor is likely of neuroendocrine origin based on histological analysis.  

Neuroendocrine tumors are a rare type of cancer. They arise from neuroendocrine cells, which have characteristics of both nerve and endocrine cells and can produce hormones in response to nerve stimuli.    

Neuroendocrine tumors can be divided into functional and nonfunctional tumors. Functional tumors produce hormones, which are responsible for the majority of their symptoms. On the other hand, nonfunctional tumors are often asymptomatic and diagnosed incidentally.    

Most neuroendocrine tumors are found within the gastrointestinal tract. Carcinoid tumors can develop in organs such as the small intestines (most commonly), large intestine, and appendix. Insulinomas, glucagonomas, and VIPomas arise in the pancreas. Furthermore, tumors such as pheochromocytoma can arise from the adrenal medulla.  

Histologically, neuroendocrine tumors can be divided into well-differentiated and poorly-differentiated neoplasms. Well-differentiated tumors are likely benign and characterized by small round cells with round to oval nuclei, inconspicuous nucleoli, and cytoplasmic granules staining positive for synaptophysin or chromogranin. In contrast, poorly-differentiated neuroendocrine neoplasms (also termed neuroendocrine carcinomas) are more likely to be malignant. These tumors are characterized by a solid “sheetlike” proliferation of tumor cells with irregular nuclei, high mitotic features, and fewer cytoplasmic secretory granules.  

Option Analysis

✅ Neuroendocrine tumor.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Adenocarcinoma :
Incorrect: Adenocarcinomas are rare appendiceal cancer and may result in appendicitis if the mass obstructs the appendiceal lumen. However, histologically, adenocarcinomas would not stain positive for synaptophysin. 
❌ Lymphoma:
Incorrect: Lymphomas can rarely develop in the appendix. However, synaptophysin granules on histological analysis are more suggestive of a neuroendocrine tumor than lymphoma.
❌ Hyperplastic adenoma:
Incorrect: Hyperplastic adenomas can sometimes develop in the appendix. However, the histological analysis would focus on mucosal hyperplasia with large goblet cells instead of cells that stain positive for synaptophysin. 
❌ Hamartoma:
Incorrect: Hamartomas can develop in the appendix, especially in patients with underlying conditions such as Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. However, synaptophysin granules on histological analysis are more suggestive of a neuroendocrine tumor than a hamartoma.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician due to abnormal menstrual cycles. The patient has not had menstrual periods for the last three months. Before developing amenorrhea, the patient has noticed decreased menstrual bleeding for several months. She has also noticed a milky discharge from the breasts. Two pregnancy tests were performed at home, and both were negative. Past medical history is unremarkable. Laboratory testing is performed and shown below. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 127/76 mmHg, and pulse is 69/min. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. This patient is at risk of developing one of the following?

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Sodium   142 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   0.9 mg/dL 
 Albumin   3.2 g/dL 
 Calcium  12 mg/dL 
 Parathyroid hormone1  85 pg/ml 
 Prolactin2  200 ng/ml 
1Referece Range: 230-630 mg/ml
2Reference Range: < 20 ng/ml
questions.solution:
This patient presents with oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, and galactorrhea. Laboratory testing is notable for elevated prolactin levels, hypercalcemia, and increased parathyroid hormone levels. These findings should raise suspicion for multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) syndrome associated with pituitary tumors, parathyroid adenomas, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.    

MEN1 syndrome is a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations of the MEN1 gene on chromosome 11. Although most cases are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, the condition can also arise secondary to de novo mutations.  



Patients with MEN1 syndrome have an increased risk for the following endocrine abnormalities:  
  •  Parathyroid tumors are the most common manifestation of MEN1 syndrome and are present in 90% of patients.  
  •  Pituitary tumors are present in 40% of patients. These are usually prolactinomas, but growth hormone-producing adenomas can also be seen. 
  •  Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors are seen in 60% of patients and arise from the islets of Langerhans. Examples of such tumors include gastrinomas (gastrin-producing tumors), insulinomas (insulin-producing tumors), glucagonomas (glucagon producing tumors), VIPomas (vasoactive peptide (VIP) producing tumors), and somatostatinomas (somatostatin producing tumors). 


Option Analysis

✅ Insulinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pheochromocytoma:
Incorrect: Pheochromocytoma is a neuroendocrine tumor that arises from the adrenal medulla. Although most cases arise sporadically, the condition can be associated with certain syndromes, such as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN2A). However, this patient has elevated prolactin levels, amenorrhea, hypercalcemia, and decreased parathyroid hormone levels. These findings suggest MEN1 syndrome, which is not associated with pheochromocytoma. 
❌ Medullary thyroid carcinoma:
Incorrect: This patient has elevated prolactin levels, amenorrhea, hypercalcemia, and decreased parathyroid hormone levels. These findings suggest multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) syndrome. In contrast, medullary thyroid carcinoma is associated with MEN2 syndrome.
❌ Mucosal neuromas:
Incorrect: Mucosal neuromas are sometimes seen in patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B (MEN2B) syndrome, but not those with MEN1 syndrome. 
❌ Cerebellar hemangioblastoma:
Incorrect: Cerebellar hemangioblastomas are associated with von Hippel Lindau (vHL) syndrome. Patients with vHL are also at increased risk for developing clear renal cell carcinoma, retinal hemangioblastomas, and pheochromocytoma. However, vHL would not account for this patient’s elevated prolactin levels, amenorrhea, hypercalcemia, or decreased parathyroid hormone levels.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman presents to her outpatient provider to evaluate weight loss over the past few months. She has noticed a 10 kg decrease in weight over the past three months despite making no changes to her appetite or diet. In addition, the patient has noticed a painful skin rash on the hands and around the mouth. She does not consume alcohol or tobacco products. Past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies and eczema. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears tired. Erythematous papules and plaques and some blisters are present on the upper extremities and around the mouth. Laboratory testing is shown below. An abdominal CT is performed and reveals a heterogeneous mass in the body of the pancreas. This patient is at the greatest risk of developing which of the following?  

Laboratory Value  Result
 Sodium   142 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   0.9 mg/dL 
 Glucose    230 mg/dL 
 Calcium  10 mg/dL

choices.text: Fibrous plaques on the right side of the heart

questions.solution:
This patient has experienced unit weight loss and erythematous papules, plaques, and blisters. Laboratory testing is notable for hyperglycemia, and a CT scan reveals a pancreatic mass. She likely has glucagonoma, which is associated with deep vein thrombosis.  

Glucagonomas are neuroendocrine pancreatic tumors arising from alpha cells within the islets of Langerhans. These tumors often secrete excess amounts of glucagon. Glucagon acts on the liver to increase glucose synthesis via stimulation of gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. Excess glucagon can lead to hyperglycemia, weight loss, and necrolytic migratory erythema (NME). NME is characterized by painful and pruritic erythematous papules and plaques that eventually develop into blisters. The rash is mainly seen on the limbs, perioral, and perigenital regions.  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Moreover, glucagonomas can manifest with diarrhea, depression, and mucosal abnormalities (e.g., stomatitis, glossitis, cheilosis). One major complication of glucagonoma is deep venous thrombosis, though the underlying pathophysiology remains unclear.  

The only definitive treatment for glucagonoma is surgical resection. However, medications can be used for symptomatic control. Somatostatin analogs (e.g. octreotide) can reverse the effects of glucagon and inhibit glucagon release. As a result, somatostatin analogs can help improve diarrhea, NME, hyperglycemia, and neurological symptoms.



Option Analysis

✅ Deep venous thrombosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypokalemia:
Incorrect: Hypokalemia can sometimes be seen in patients with VIPoma, another neuroendocrine tumor. VIPomas can present with achlorhydria, watery diarrhea, and hypokalemia. However, this patient more likely has glucagonoma, which is not associated with hypokalemia.
❌ Jejunal ulcers:
Incorrect: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is caused by gastrinoma and is characterized by excessive gastrin and gastric acid production. The excess acid can lead to ulcers in the stomach and intestines. However, this patient’s rash and elevated blood glucose level suggest a glucagonoma.  
❌ Cholecystitis:
Incorrect: Somatostatinoma is a neuroendocrine tumor that can lead to cholecystitis secondary to decreased cholecystokinin production and decreased gallbladder motility. Somatistinomas can also present with steatorrhea, hyperglycemia, and achlorhydria. However, a somatostatinoma would not account for the erythematous papules, plaques, and blisters present in this patient.
❌ Fibrous plaques on the right side of the heart:
Incorrect: Carcinoid tumors secrete excessive amounts of serotonin, which stimulates the growth of fibroblasts and can lead to fibrous plaque formation in the right heart. Although carcinoid tumors can arise in the pancreas, they are not associated with necrolytic migratory erythema or hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents to the physician due to recurrent abdominal pain. The pain is triggered by fatty foods, persists for around 3 hours after meals, and is most prominent in the right upper abdominal quadrant. In addition, she has had foul-smelling diarrhea that floats in the toilet bowl. Last month, she was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus and initiated metformin therapy. The patient does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Past medical history is notable for constipation and hypertension. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 147/89 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. An abdominal CT scan is performed and reveals a mass in the head of the pancreas. A biopsy is taken, and the cells stain positive for synaptophysin. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Malignant proliferation of pancreatic ductal epithelium
Uncontrolled proliferation of cells that secrete vasoactive inhibitory peptides
Neuroendocrine tumor characterized by excess gastrin release

questions.solution:
This patient has steatorrhea, hyperglycemia, and findings concerning cholelithiasis. She has a tumor in the pancreatic head that stains positive for synaptophysin, a marker for neuroendocrine tumors. As a result, she likely has a somatostatinoma, which occurs due to the proliferation of delta cells within the islets of Langerhans.  

Somatostatinomas are a type of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor. They can be functional or non-functional, depending on whether the tumor secretes somatostatin. Non-functional tumors are usually asymptomatic, and the pathology is discovered incidentally. However, functional tumors cause symptoms secondary to excess somatostatin production.    

Somatostatin is an inhibitory hormone that blocks the production of various gastrointestinal hormones, including insulin, glucagon, gastrin, and cholecystokinin (CKK). Furthermore, somatostatin inhibits gastric emptying, acid production, and pancreatic exocrine secretions.  

Clinically, patients with functional tumors may develop the triad of diabetes mellitus (due to decreased insulin production), cholelithiasis (due to decreased CCK production and subsequent cholestasis), and steatorrhea (due to decreased pancreatic exocrine secretions and decreased nutrient absorption from the gastrointestinal tract). Furthermore, some patients may have hypochlorhydria due to decreased gastrin and gastric acid production.  

Diagnosis can be made via laboratory testing followed by imaging and biopsy confirmation. Surgical resection is the only curative treatment. However, symptomatic control can be achieved by administering octreotide, a somatostatin analog that acts directly on the tumor cells. Octreotide reduces somatostatin production and thereby helps improve symptoms.

Option Analysis

✅ Neoplasm of pancreatic delta-cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Malignant proliferation of pancreatic ductal epithelium:
Incorrect: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma can arise from the malignant proliferation of pancreatic ductal cells. The condition typically develops in elderly individuals with a history of smoking or heavy alcohol consumption; in contrast, this patient lacks those risk factors. Furthermore, adenocarcinomas would not stain positive for synaptophysin.
❌ Uncontrolled proliferation of cells that secrete vasoactive inhibitory peptides:
Incorrect: VIPomas are pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors that produce excessive vasoactive inhibitory peptides (VIP). The condition is associated with the triad of watery diarrhea, hypochlorhydria, and hypokalemia. In contrast, a VIPoma would typically not cause cholelithiasis or steatorrhea. 
❌ Neoplasm of pancreatic alpha-cells:
Incorrect: Glucagonomas are pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors arising from alpha-cells within the islets of Langerhans. These tumors will cause hyperglycemia and stain positive for synaptophysin. However, glucagonomas are not associated with cholelithiasis or steatorrhea. 
❌ Neuroendocrine tumor characterized by excess gastrin release:
Incorrect: Gastrinomas are a type of neuroendocrine tumor that can arise in the pancreas and stain positive for synaptophysin. Gastrinomas can cause recurrent peptic ulcers, abdominal pain, and acid reflux. However, the condition would not typically cause cholelithiasis, hyperglycemia, and steatorrhea.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the physician for evaluation of diarrhea for the last three months. The patient has been having multiple episodes of watery, “tea-colored” diarrhea each day. Diarrhea persists even when he has little or no oral intake. He has also felt fatigued during the day and often experiences muscle cramps. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and seasonal allergies. The patient does not take any medications. He does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 117/75 mmHg, and pulse is 86/min. On physical examination, the mucosal membranes appear dry, and capillary refill is delayed. Laboratory testing is notable for hypokalemia and elevated serum levels of a peptide hormone that promotes the release of water and electrolytes into the gastrointestinal lumen. Fecal osmotic gap is 40 mOsm/kg. Abdominal CT reveals a mass in the head of the pancreas. Which of the following additional findings is expected to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Erythematous papules and plaques in the perigenital area

questions.solution:
This patient presents with persistent watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and muscle cramps. Laboratory testing reveals increased hormone levels that promote the release of water and electrolytes into the gastrointestinal lumen. He likely has a VIPoma, leading to reduced gastric acid secretion.  

VIPomas are rare neuroendocrine tumors that almost always arise in the pancreas. The condition is characterized by excess vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) production. VIP is a peptide hormone that promotes vasodilation, smooth muscle relaxation, secretion of ions and water into the intestines, and inhibits gastric acid secretion.    

Patients with VIPoma usually present with watery diarrhea secondary to excessive ion and water secretion into the intestinal lumen. Diarrhea can persist during sleep or periods of fasting. The stools are usually odorless and tea-colored, leading to massive loss of fluids and electrolytes over time.  

Furthermore, excessive secretion of potassium from the epithelial cells of the intestinal tract can cause hypokalemia, which can manifest with lethargy, muscle weakness, and cramps. Moreover, since VIP suppresses gastric acid secretions, patients with VIPoma will have hypochlorhydria or achlorhydria. As a result, the syndrome associated with VIPomas has termed WDHA syndrome ( Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, Achlorhydria). In some cases, patients may also develop facial flushing and hyperglycemia (since VIP promotes glycogenolysis). 

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased gastric acid secretion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Gallbladder hypomotility:
Incorrect: Somatostatinomas are associated with decreased levels of cholecystokinin, which in turn causes decreased gallbladder motility and an increased risk for developing gallstones. In addition, patients with somatostatinomas may experience steatorrhea and hyperglycemia. However, somatostatinomas would not typically present with the hypokalemia or watery diarrhea seen in this patient. 
❌ Jejunal ulcers:
Incorrect: Gastrinomas are associated with increased gastric acid production, which may lead to jejunal ulcers. However, this patient’s history of frequent watery stools and hypokalemia suggests VIPomas. VIPomas are associated with decreased gastric acid production.
❌ Erythematous papules and plaques in the perigenital area:
Incorrect: Necrotizing migratory erythema is characterized by erythematous papules and plaques that can be found in the perioral and perigenital areas as well as on the limbs. It is seen in patients with glucagonomas, not VIPomas.
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia can be seen in patients with insulinomas. However, this patient’s history of watery diarrhea and laboratory finding of hypokalemia is more suggestive of a VIPoma. VIPomas are more likely to cause hyperglycemia rather than hypoglycemia due to the ability of vasoactive inhibitory peptide (VIP) to increase glycogenolysis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate blurry vision and dizziness. Her symptoms started around an hour ago. In addition, she is sweating and feels “as if my heart were racing”. While in the emergency room, the patient faints and collapses. Finger dipstick glucose level is measured to be 50 mg/dL. The patient is immediately given glucose. She regains consciousness, and her symptoms subsequently improve. The patient has had several similar episodes over the past month. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 120/81 mmHg, and pulse is 97/min. Serum analysis reveals elevated insulin and C-peptide levels. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient's history is notable for palpitations, blurry vision, dizziness, loss of consciousness, and hypoglycemia. These symptoms resolve after glucose administration. Furthermore, her serum insulin and C-peptide levels are elevated. In combination, these findings are concerning for insulinoma.  

Insulinomas are rare pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors that arise from ꞵ-cells within the islets of Langerhans. Most cases are sporadic, although the condition can sometimes be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) syndrome.    

Insulinomas secrete insulin inappropriately and irrespective of serum glucose levels. As a result, patients with insulinomas are at risk of developing Whipple triad, which consists of hypoglycemia, hypoglycemic symptoms, and resolution of symptoms with glucose administration. Symptoms of hypoglycemia can include blurry vision, confusion, and in severe cases, seizures and coma. Moreover, patients may develop symptoms of adrenergic activation such as palpitations, sweating, and tremulousness.      

Insulinomas must be differentiated from excess exogenous insulin administration. While both conditions present with similar symptoms, a C-peptide level can be used to differentiate the two. C-peptide is a protein produced from ꞵ-cells in conjugation with insulin. Since patients with exogenous insulin use have low endogenous insulin production, C-peptide levels will be low. In contrast, patients with insulinomas will have high endogenous insulin production and elevated C-peptide levels.  



Option Analysis

✅ Insulinoma :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Exogenous insulin use:
Incorrect: Exogenous insulin use can cause hypoglycemia and associated symptoms, including dizziness, blurry vision, palpitations, and anxiety. However, serum C-peptide levels would be low in patients who inject exogenous insulin. 
❌ Glucagonoma:
Incorrect: Glucagonoma is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor associated with increased glucagon production. These patients are at risk for hyperglycemia instead of hypoglycemia. 
❌ VIPoma :
Incorrect: VIPoma is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor associated with increased vasoactive inflammatory peptides (VIP) production. Patients can develop the triad of hypokalemia, secretory diarrhea, and achlorhydria. It is not associated with hypoglycemia.
❌ Somatostatinoma :
Incorrect: Somatostatinoma is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor associated with increased somatostatin production. Somatostatin inhibits the synthesis of gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP), which promotes insulin release. As a result, a somatostatinoma would decrease insulin production and elevate blood glucose levels.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician due to midline abdominal pain that has been ongoing for several months. The pain is described as a burning sensation and worsens after meals. As a result, the patient has been eating less and has experienced a 5 kg (11 lb) weight loss. She has a history of peptic ulcer disease, which was diagnosed last year. She was prescribed omeprazole but has not noticed an improvement in symptoms after initiating therapy. Medical history is also notable for low back pain. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness to palpation of the epigastric region. An endoscopy is performed and shows multiple ulcers in the stomach and duodenum. A urea breath test is negative. Administration of intravenous secretin is followed by an increase in serum gastrin levels by 200 pg/mL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has peptic ulcer disease refractory to treatment. In addition, a secretin test returns positive. These findings suggest that Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES) is secondary to gastrinoma, a type of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor.  

Most gastrinomas arise in either the duodenum or pancreas. Gastrinomas can arise sporadically, with a median age between 20-50, or as part of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) syndrome.  

The pathophysiology of gastrinomas is related to the oversecretion of gastrin, which stimulates gastric parietal cells to produce excess acid. The acid causes gastric and duodenal ulcers that are usually multiple, recurrent, and refractory to treatment. Since so much acid is produced, ulcers can even form in areas of the gastrointestinal tract far from the stomach (e.g. jejunum).    

Moreover, the increase in duodenal acidity deactivates pancreatic enzymes and damages epithelial cells. These changes impair food absorption, causing chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss.    

The diagnosis of ZES can be challenging. Patients will often have elevated serum gastrin levels and increased stomach acidity. In addition, a secretin stimulation test can be used to assist with diagnosis. Secretin normally inhibits gastrin and gastric acid release. However, secretin administration leads to paradoxical elevations in gastrin levels in patients with gastrinomas.  



Option Analysis

✅ Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ NSAID use  :
Incorrect: NSAIDs can prevent the release of prostaglandins, which have a protective effect on the gastric mucosa, and cause gastric ulcers. However, a positive secretin test is indicative of gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.   
❌ Helicobacter pylori infection:
Incorrect: The infection of Helicobacter pylori (H.Pylori) is the most common cause of peptic ulcer disease. However, a negative urea breath test and a positive secretin test are more suggestive of gastrinoma than H.pylori infection.
❌ Stress ulcer:
Incorrect: Stress ulcers are seen in severely ill patients (e.g. ICU patients). Stress ulcers are related to decreased blood flow to the stomach, increasing mucosal injury risk.
❌ Cushing ulcer:
Incorrect: A Cushing ulcer is a gastric ulcer that develops in the setting of elevated intracranial pressure. The increase in intracranial pressure causes vagal nerve overactivation, which results in acid oversecretion. However, a secretin test would be negative in patients with Cushing ulcers.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the office because of several weeks of vague abdominal pain and increased fatigue. The pain is localized to the right upper quadrant of the abdomen and is non-radiating. He has not had chest pain, fever, or cough. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include lisinopril and metformin. Family history is noncontributory. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor and a mildly distended soft abdomen. The liver edge is hard and is palpated 8 cm below the costal margin. The cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Fecal occult blood testing is positive. Laboratory results are shown below. Chest X-ray is unremarkable. CT scan of the abdomen is shown. After an appropriate workup, a definitive diagnosis is established. The patient declines surgery and wishes to continue with pharmacological therapy. In addition to 5-fluorouracil, a topoisomerase I inhibitor is added to the regimen. Which of the following is the most likely agent that is added? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Hemoglobin     8 g/dL    
 Leukocyte count     8000/mm3    
 Platelet count       230,000/mm3    
 Mean corpuscular volume     68 μm3    
 Serum     
 Creatinine      0.9 g/dL    
 BUN     12 g/dL    
 Alanine aminotransferase      57 U/L    
 Aspartate aminotransferase      38 U/L    


Reproduced by Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient with abdominal pain and distention, microcytic anemia, positive fecal blood test, and hepatomegaly has multiple liver lesions on the CT scan, most likely due to undiagnosed colon cancer with metastasis to the liver. A combination of 5-fluorouracil and irinotecan (topoisomerase I inhibitor) represents one of the options of therapy for metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).        

Topoisomerases are enzymes that relieve the DNA supercoiling that occurs during DNA replication as a result of the separation and unwinding of the DNA. Topoisomerase I makes single-stranded nicks to relieve negative supercoiling. Topoisomerase I inhibitors (e.g., topotecan and irinotecan) are synthetic derivatives of 20 (S)-camptothecin, a natural product from the Camptotheca acuminata tree. They bind to and stabilize a transient TOPO I–DNA complex, resulting in double-strand breakage and lethal DNA damage. A few of the important features of topotecan and irinotecan are tabulated above.   

Option Analysis

❌ Etoposide :
Incorrect: Etoposide is a topoisomerase II inhibitor that increases DNA degradation by arresting the cell cycle in G2 and S phases. Although it is used in the management of solid tumors (testicular and small cell lung cancer), it is not indicated in the management of metastatic colorectal cancer. 
✅ Irinotecan :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Topotecan :
Incorrect: Although topotecan is a topoisomerase I inhibitor, it is usually used in the management of ovarian and small cell lung cancer. It is not indicated in this patient. 
❌ Paclitaxel :
Incorrect: Paclitaxel is a microtubule inhibitor that hyper-stabilizes the polymerized microtubules in M phase so that the mitotic spindle cannot break down. It is usually indicated in the management of ovarian cancer. 
❌ Cladribine :
Incorrect: Cladribine is a purine analog that inhibits DNA synthesis by inhibiting DNA polymerase and by inducing DNA strand breaks. It, however, does not affect topoisomerase I and is mainly indicated in the management of hairy cell leukemia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate diarrhea and skin flushing. The patient has had almost daily episodes of diarrhea, which sometimes awaken her at night. She also notices that her skin turns red every time she drinks alcohol, and these episodes last around 20 minutes. The patient has also experienced intermittent shortness of breath and wheezing, which she attributes to seasonal allergies. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, anxiety, and seasonal allergies. She has had irregular menstrual cycles for the past four months. She does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is noncontributory. The patient is provided a somatostatin analog for treatment. Which of the following medications was provided?
questions.solution:
Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that arise from enterochromaffin cells. They most often occur in the small intestines but can also develop in the appendix, pancreas, and lungs.  

Carcinoid tumors produce excess serotonin. Most serotonin is transported to the liver via portal circulation and broken down by first-pass hepatic metabolism. Therefore, the serotonin does not reach the systemic circulation to cause symptoms. However, carcinoid syndrome develops when serotonin escapes first-pass hepatic metabolism and enters the systemic circulation, such as when cancer metastasizes to extraintestinal sites (e.g. liver).    

Clinical features of carcinoid syndrome are due to serotonin’s effects on various tissues. Serotonin stimulates gut motility in the gastrointestinal tract, resulting in secretory diarrhea. In the skin, serotonin’s vasodilatory effects cause skin flushing, lasting anywhere from 30 seconds to 30 minutes. The flushing can be precipitated by emotional or physical stress and alcohol use. In the lungs, serotonin causes bronchoconstriction, leading to wheezing and dyspnea. Finally, serotonin stimulates fibroblast growth in cardiac tissues, resulting in plaque-like fibrous deposits on the valves, cardiac chambers, and major vessels. These cardiac effects are mainly seen in the right heart and can lead to heart failure and valvular disease.  



Histologically, carcinoid tumor cells are arranged in trabeculae or nests. Cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm and round/oval nuclei filled with fine granules. Like many other neuroendocrine tumors, immunostaining is positive for chromogranin and synaptophysin.    

Carcinoid syndrome can be treated with surgical resection and somatostatin analogs, such as octreotide. Somatostatin receptors are highly expressed in the tumor cells. As a result, somatostatin analogs can control symptoms, reduce tumor growth, and improve patient survival.  



Option Analysis

✅ Octreotide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Glucagon :
Incorrect: lucagon is the primary catabolic hormone in the body, it is not a somatostatin analog. 
❌ Growth hormone:
Incorrect: Growth hormone is not a somatostatin analog, nor is it used to treat patients with carcinoid syndrome. 
❌ Diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Diphenhydramine is a first-generation antihistamine. Although diphenhydramine can treat seasonal allergies, this medication is not used to treat carcinoid syndrome.
❌ Aspirin :
Incorrect: Aspirin can be used to manage flush associated with niacin use. Aspirin, however, has no role in the management of carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text: During a tumor board meeting, the oncology team is asked to review the clinical therapy for a 63-year-old man who had a recently resected colonic tumor. Gross pathology shows that the tumor was large and nearly completely obstructing the colonic lumen. A recent PET scan conducted on this patient shows distant metastases which have penetrated the liver. The oncology team proposes starting the patient on the FOLFOX chemotherapy regimen. Before initiating therapy, the team proposes using a medication that will prime the patient’s immune system by increasing the immune visibility of the tumor. The patient is treated with cetuximab and is found to have little effect on metastatic tumor populations on imaging. A biopsy of the metastatic liver deposits is taken. A mutation in which of the following receptors is most likely?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a patient with a newly diagnosed stage IV colon cancer with metastases to the liver. Standard treatment for stage IV colon cancers includes either FOLFOX (Folinic acid, Fluorouracil, and Oxaliplatin) or FOLFIRI (Folinic acid, Fluorouracil, irinotecan) chemotherapy regimens. Before starting either of these chemotherapy regimens, it is now common to “prime” the patient’s immune system with targeted monoclonal antibodies, which help the patient’s immune system increase the immune visibility of tumor cells.    

Approximately 60-80% of cancer cells in colorectal tumors overexpress the EGFR receptor. Both  Cetuximab and Panitumumab are monoclonal antibody therapies targeted against the EGFR receptor used in the treatment of stage IV colorectal cancer and some head and neck tumors. Panitumumab is a human monoclonal antibody, whereas Cetuximab is a chimeric mouse monoclonal antibody. Both Cetuximab and Panitumumab have similar side effects, including rash, elevated LFTs, and diarrhea. Neither therapy is more efficacious in the treatment of colorectal cancer. A key difference between the two drugs is the role that cetuximab plays in immunological priming. Cetuximab has been shown to increase ADCC and other immunostimulatory activities such as cell maturation, T-cell recruitment to the tumor, increased antigen presentation, and cytotoxic NK T-cell priming. On the other hand, Panitumumab notably does not engage in cytotoxic NK T-cell priming. It does, however, engage in immune cytotoxicity at a much lower extent via neutrophil-driven ADCC. While it remains to be seen which of these drugs are superior in clinical efficacy, it’s clear that cetuximab has robust effects in modulating immune cytotoxic effects in cancer cells.   

Option Analysis

❌ VEGF:
Incorrect: This patient initially received cetuximab, which targets EGFR. A mutation in EGFR is most likely the cause of the tumor’s non-responsiveness to treatment.
❌ HER2:
Incorrect: Mutations in HER2 occur in breast cancers, not colorectal cancers. 
❌ CD20 :
Incorrect: CD20 is a pan-B-Cell marker useful in diagnosing and treating leukemia. 
❌ KIT:
Incorrect: Mutations in KIT are common in gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs)
✅ EGFR:
Correct: See main explanation.
